oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: The History of Country Music - Volume 1 - Recording 1 - Side 2
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Country music history program with voice overs and commercial recordings prepared for radio broadcast. Internet sources say the producer and narrator is Lee Cash. Subject matter pertains to the history of country music, and recording is likely a syndicated radio show. Tape demonstrates recordings from 1944-1954. Tape is labeled as: volume one, recording one, side two.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) The History of Country Music (Unconfirmed) ([Unidentified]) -- (00:05) An unidentified speaker introduces the D-Day Radio Message -- (00:18) Dwight D. Eisenhower gives his D-Day message -- (00:33) An unidentified voice introduces "There's a Star Spangled Banner Waving Somewhere" -- (00:43) There's a Star Spangled Banner Waving Somewhere (Elton Britt) -- (03:08) An unidentified speaker introduces Amos and Andy -- (03:19) A clip is played from the Amos and Andy Show -- (03:35) An unidentified voice introduces "Ghost Riders in the Sky" -- (03:46) Ghost Riders in the Sky (Vaughn Monroe) -- (06:29) I'm Moving on [featuring Hank Snow Voiceover] (Hank Snow) -- (09:16) An unidentified speaks on the reputation of Chet Atkins -- (09:35) Mother Maybelle Carter speaks on the difficulties of people's acceptance of Atkins -- (09:54) Atkins reflects on his rough start in Nashville -- (10:11) [Unidentified] (Chet Atkins) -- (11:57) An unidentified speaker introduces the instrumentation of Del Wood -- (12:15) Down Yonder (Del Wood) -- (14:38) There's a Rainbow in Every Teardrop (Slim Whitman) -- (17:03) An unidentified speaker discusses the music of 1953 and introduces "I Forgot More Than You'' Ever Know" -- (17:17) I Forgot More Than You'll Ever Know (Betty and Skeeter Davis) -- (20:09) An unidentified speaker discusses the music of 1954 and introduces "This Old House" -- (20:28) This Old House (Stuart Hamblen) -- (23:09) The History of Country Music (Unconfirmed) ([Unidentified])
